questiontext.text:
Solve the following word problems leading to quadratic equations.


(a) The difference between a number and its positive square root is {@difference@}.

Find the number.

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

[[feedback:prt1]]


(b) The sides of an equilateral triangle are each shortened by \({@c@} \text{cm}\), \({@a@} \text{cm}\) and \({@b@} \text{cm}\) respectively. The result is a right-angled triangle.

Find the length of the sides of the equilateral triangle.

[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] \(\text{cm}\)

[[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

(a) We will call the required number \(n\).

If the difference between the number and itâ€™s positive square root is {@difference@}, we have,

\(\begin{align*} n-\sqrt{n} = {@difference@} & \Rightarrow n-{@difference@} = \sqrt{n} \\ & \Rightarrow (n-{@difference@})^{2} = (\sqrt{n})^{2} \\ & \Rightarrow {@expand((n-difference)^2)@} = n \\ & \Rightarrow {@expand((n-difference)^2) - n@} = 0 \end{align*}\)

So, we have derived a quadratic equation for \(n\) which we may solve by factorizing,

\(\begin{align*} {@expand((n-difference)^2)-n@} &= {@eqn@} \\ &= 0 \end{align*}\)

\(\Rightarrow n = {@n1@}, n = {@n2@}\)


By squaring the equation, we may have introduced additional solutions.
So, we need to verify that the solutions we have derived actually solve the original problem.

Firstly, we consider \(n = {@ta1@}\),

\({@ta1@} - \sqrt{{@ta1@}} = {@difference@}\)

Therefore, this solution does solve the original problem.

Then, we consider \(n = {@wrong_sol@}\),

\({@wrong_sol@} - \sqrt{{@wrong_sol@}} = {@wrong_sol-sqrt(wrong_sol)@} \neq {@difference@}\)

Therefore, this solution does not solve the original problem.


Hence, the only solution to the original problem is {@ta@}.


(b) We will call the length of the sides of the equilateral triangle \(x\).

Then, the sides of right-angled triangle have lengths \({@hypotenuse@}, {@height@}\) and \({@base@}\).

The side with length {@hypotenuse@} is the longest side in the right-angled triangle, so we can apply Pythagoras' Theorem so give,

\(\begin{align*} a^2 + b^2 = c^2 &\Rightarrow {@height^2@} + {@base^2@} = {@hypotenuse^2@} \\ &\Rightarrow ({@expand(height^2)@}) + ({@expand(base^2)@}) = ({@expand(hypotenuse^2)@}) \\ &\Rightarrow {@expr4@} = 0 \end{align*}\)

So, we have derived a quadratic equation for \(x\) which we may solve by factorizing,

\(\begin{align*} {@expr4@} &= {@expr@} \\ &= 0 \end{align*}\)

\(\Rightarrow x = {@x1@}, x = {@x2@}\)


Considering now the context of the problem, since they represent the lengths of the sides of a triangle the values of \({@hypotenuse@}, {@height@}\) and \({@base@}\) must be positive.

Therefore, \(x \neq {@x2@}\)

So, the length of each side of the equilateral triangle is \({@ta2@} \text{cm}\).
